items.message:
River levels continue to remain high on Bristol Avon, Tetbury Avon and Dauntsey Brook and the Sherston Avon. Approximately 5 to 10 mm of rain has fallen in the last 24 hours over the catchment. The unsettled weather continues, further rain is expected today, Saturday the 18th November and Sunday the 19th November, which will continue to maintain high river levels. No Flood Warnings are currently forecast to be issued in this Flood Alert area.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels, checking rivers for blockages and clearing debris from weed screens in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated on Sunday morning, or sooner if the situation changes.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall on the Lower Dorset Frome due to heavy rainfall.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Lower Dorset Frome, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Dorchester and Wareham.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated byÂ 22/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thame, Horsenden Stream and Chalgrove Brook

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Thame, Horsenden Stream, Chalgrove Brook

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are steady on the River Thame as a result of overnight rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially in the Thame, Stadhampton, and Dorchester areas. Further rain is forecast this morning, 18/11/23, with further unsettled weather expected over the coming week with low confidence over exact locations and timings of rain. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow, 19/11/23, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.    
Further rainfall is forecast however, we continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking the condition of defences.

River levels are starting to rise on the River Rye Catchment due to rainfall this morning. Areas most at risk include land around the River Rye and it's tributaries, including Ralsdale Beck, River Seph, Ledge Beck, Fangdale Beck, Prodale Beck, Ladhill Beck, Etton Gill, Borough Beck, Spittle Beck, including properties of Salton, Nunnington and Helmsley. Further rainfall is forecast for the next few days. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 8pm on 18/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels are starting to rise on the River Seven Catchment due to rainfall this morning. Areas most at risk include land around the River Seven and it's tributaries including Northdale Beck, Hartoft Beck, Ings Beck, Lastingham Beck, Sutherland Beck, Cropton Beck, Catter Beck, including properties in Sinnington and to the east of Normanby. Further rainfall is forecast for the next few days. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 8pm on 18/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Camel, River Allen, Bodmin Town Leat, River Valency

items.message:
Organised bands of rainfall will move across the county from mid-afternoon on Friday 17th November, until late morning Saturday. There may be some intense localised downpours during the early hours. Overall accumulations across the period could be up to 20mm widely, and up to 40mm on higher ground. This could lead to further rises in river levels, peaking during the early hours and into Saturday morning, which may result in flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river.   

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated on Saturday morning or earlier if the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brathay, River Rothay, River Winster

items.message:
River and lake levels remain high but are beginning to fall on the Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster due to recent rainfall.
Areas most at risk include the Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster and other watercourses, from Grasmere to Grange-over-Sands including low lying areas around Ambleside, Skelwith Bridge, Windermere, Hawkshead, Newby Bridge, Backbarrow, Cark and Cartmel. Flooding of low lying land and roads is possible in these areas. 
Further light rainfall is forecast over the weekend before an improved forecast for early next week. 
The Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster and Lake Windermere will remain high today, but we do not expect any flooding to properties.
We will continue to monitor levels closely over the weekend. 
Newby Bridge sluices remain open due to high lake levels. 
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 19/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message:
Lake levels on Derwent Water and river levels in Borrowdale remain high due to recent rainfall.
Areas most at risk include low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwent Water and low lying areas in Borrowdale.
River and lake levels are expected to remain high throughout Saturday and into Sunday.
Further light rainfall is forecast on Saturday and Sunday before the forecast improves early in the week.
We will continue to monitor levels closely over the weekend.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 19/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

Lake levels on Derwent Water remain high due to recent rainfall.
Areas most at risk include low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwent Water and the frontage of the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site.
Lake levels are expected to remain high throughout Saturday and into Sunday.
Further light rainfall is forecast on Saturday and Sunday keeping lake levels high at the Lodore gauge.
We will continue to monitor levels closely over the weekend.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 19/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected this morning, 18/11/2023.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high over the weekend.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 21:00 this evening, 18/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels are forecast to rise on the River Alt.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Alt, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around River Alt and other watercourses from Huyton to Hightown including, Kirkby, Fazakerley, Maghull, Formby, Aughton, Sefton and Lunt.
Flooding is possible at River Alt and other watercourses from Huyton to Hightown including, Kirkby, Fazakerley, Maghull, Formby, Aughton, Sefton and Lunt from 03:00 AM on 18/11/2023.
Further light rainfall is forecast overnight.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 09:00 AM on 18/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.message: The risk of flooding in the River Dart area has now reduced, the rainfall forecast reduced overnight and river levels are falling below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days. Further rainfall is forecast throughout the weekend and we will continue to monitor the situation

items.message: River levels remain high on the River Ouse in response to recent rainfall. Flooding is expected along riverside footpaths and low-lying land in York and to the south as far as Naburn Lock, including Kings Staith, Queens Staith, and South Esplanade. The River Ouse is falling slowly, however, we expect levels to stay high in response to further rainfall today and tomorrow. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 11pm on 18/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated on Saturday morning or earlier if the situation changes.

items.message: River levels remain high on the River Derwent due to rainfall associated with Storm Debi. Areas most at risk include the Upper Derwent areas, including land around Old Malton, Low Marishes and Priorpot Beck in Norton. Further rain is forecast for the next few days and levels are expected to rise again. We will continue to monitor the forecast. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 8pm on 18/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.message: River levels remain high on the lower River Derwent due to recent heavy rain associated with Storm Debi. Areas most at risk include local roads and low-lying land around Stamford Bridge, Pocklington, Wressle, Wilberfoss and Elvington. Further rain is forecast for the next few days and levels are expected to rise again. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please monitor local weather and river conditions and avoid contact with, walking or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 8pm on 18/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Horner Water, River Aller, Washford River, Hawkcombe Stream, Monksilver Stream, Doniford Stream

items.message:
After a mostly dry Friday, a band of rain will return early Saturday morning through to late afternoon. The Washford River remains high and the Horner Water, River Aller, Hawkcombe Stream, Monksilver Stream and Doniford Stream will rise in response to the overnight rainfall. There is the continuing possibility for flooding of low-lying land and roads. 
Unsettled weather will continue through the weekend and into Monday 20 November. 
Please consider weather conditions, local water levels and your flood plan if you have one. Avoid using low-lying footpaths, roads and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
We will continue to monitor the rainfall and river levels and our staff are checking flood defences and clearing weed screens.
This message will be updated by 1pm on 18/11/2023.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Hillfarrance Brook, Halsewater Stream, River Tone

items.message:
After a mostly dry Friday, a band of rain will return early Saturday morning through to late afternoon. Unsettled weather will continue through the weekend and into Monday 20 November. River levels are forecast to rise on the River Tone, Hillfarrance Brook, Halsewater Stream due to the overnight rainfall. The flooding of low-lying land and roads could occur from approximately 07:30 Saturday morning. No property flooding is expected at this time. 
We will continue to monitor the rainfall and river levels and our staff are checking flood defences and clearing weed screens. 
Avoid using low lying footpaths and roads near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 1pm on Saturday 18/11/2023.

Further rainfall is forecast throughout the weekend and we will continue to monitor the situation.

items.description: Rivers Clyst and Culm and their tributaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Rivers Clyst and Culm 
Flooding is possible in the early hours of Saturday morning. 
Widespread heavy rainfall is forecast overnight across Devon. This will cause rivers in the area to rise.  
The main areas of concern are Cullompton, Willand, Culmstock, Hemyock, Bradninch, Broadclyst and Clyst St Mary. River levels suggest that there will be flooding to low lying land and roads close to rivers.
We expect rivers to remain high throughout Saturday. 
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. 
We are constantly monitoring river levels. This message will be updated if the situation changes.

items.description: Creyke, Mill and Broadlane Becks at Cottingham
items.message: River levels are rising quickly on Broadlane Beck and Creyke Beck due to heavy rainfall. Areas most at risk include properties around King Street, Northgate, Dunswell Road, and North Moor Lane. This means properties are at risk of flooding. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please take action to protect yourself and your property and monitor local weather and river conditions. Avoid contact with, walking or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 3pm on 18/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, Kingston upon Hull

items.message: River levels are rising in the Cottingham area due to recent rainfall. The areas most at risk include Cottingham, Kirk Ella, Anlaby and Hessle. Further rainfall is forecast for the next few days. We will continue to monitor the forecast. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated at 7PM on 18/11/2023 or as the situation changes.

The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.51 m and steady. Water will enter Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45 m.
The drain level at Currymoor is 5.79 m and is slowly rising. 
After a mostly dry Friday, a band of rain will return early Saturday morning through to late afternoon. Unsettled weather will continue through the weekend and into Monday 20 November. 
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels closely. 
We are pumping at Currymoor and Saltmoor pumping stations when river levels allow and have deployed additional temporary pumps at both stations and at Elsonâs Clyce. The Parrett Relief Channel is being used to evacuate the water away.
Please consider weather conditions, local water levels and your flood plan if you have one. Avoid using low lying footpaths, roads and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated before 1pm on Saturday 18 November.

Strong winds and spring tides may cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast tomorrow morning. Areas most at risk include The North Sea coast from Bridlington to Barmston. Flooding is possible at the North Sea coast from Bridlington to BarmstonÂ between 5am and 12pm on Saturday, 18/11/2023. After this tideâ the weather is more settled and no further impacts are expected. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 2pm on 18/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Cae Howel river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Actual peak:-  Llanymynech 4.3m on Tuesday afternoon, 14/11/23 and Cae Howel 4.9m on Wednesday afternoon 15/11/23. 
Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days with further peaks possible.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated by 10:00 on 19/11/23, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council, Hampshire

items.message:
A Flood Alert has been issued by the Environment Agency. 

Flood Alert in force: Lower Avon and tributaries. 

Flooding is possible for: Tributaries between Ringwood and Christchurch.    

Be prepared.

 River levels are high but steady at the Ringwood Old Cottage river gauge as a result of the ground being saturated and reacting to further rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  We expect flooding to affect tributaries between Ringwood and Christchurch   
  
We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated Wednesday, 22/11/23, or as the situation changes. 

To check the latest information for your area

items.description: River Blackwater and The Cove Brook
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.

River levels are stable on the River Blackwater. This morning's 18/11/23 rain will gradually clear to leave a dry day. We expect river levels to rise this afternoon in response to the recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of roads and low lying land remains possible.

We are closely monitoring the situation. 

Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated this evening 18/11/23 or if the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Ouse from Naburn Lock to Selby
items.message: River levels remain high on the tidal Ouse in response to recent heavy rainfall in the upper catchments. Areas most at risk include the tidal foreshore and agricultural land adjacent to the river in the Cawood, Kelfield, Wistow and Selby areas. The River Ouse is falling slowly in York, however further rainfall is forecast today and tomorrow and we expect levels to stay high. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 11pm on 18/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days with further peaks possible.

Please avoid contact with flood water and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.

River levels have risen at the Leek river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible this morning.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Churnet between Leek and Rocester and the River Tean between Adderley and Spath including Cecilly Brook at Cheadle.  We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely today, Saturday 18th November. Water levels continue to remain high and may last for the next few days. This is due to a natural tide locking effect of the Broads river system combined with the recent rainfall across the area. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning. The weather forecast is for light rain today, Saturday 18th November. Further rain is due tomorrow. Flood water is dangerous. Don't put yourself or others at risk. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths. We are closely monitoring the situation. We will update this message on Sunday 19th November, or as the situation changes.

We expect river levels to rise until later this afternoon.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated In the next 8 hours.

Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially in the Abingdon and Culham areas.  Further rain is forecast this morning, 18/11/23, with further unsettled weather expected over the coming week with low confidence over exact locations and timings of rain. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Water levels in the Eastern Yar remain high. Since Thursday morning (16/11/2023), only small amounts of rain (2mm) have been recorded at Knighton. This has allowed the river level at Alverstone to fall slowly after peaking at around 04:30 this morning (Friday 17/11/2023). At Sandown, the river is likely to continue rising until at least 18:00 this evening. More heavy rain is forecast. Up to 30mm could fall between 22:30 tonight (17/11/2023) and 14:30 tomorrow (18/11/2023). If the worst of this rain affects the Eastern Yar, property flooding is possible around Alverstone and Langbridge from 19:00 on Saturday (18/11/2023). At Sandown, levels will take longer to rise and impacts might be possible from approximately 08:00 on Sunday (19/11/2023). We are operating the sluice at Bembridge to manage the water level and continue to monitor the forecast. Please ensure that any pumps used to reduce water levels in gardens can operate. This Flood Alert will be updated by 15:00 on 18/11/2023.

items.description: The Rivers Blyth and Walpole and Chediston, Bramfield and Wrentham watercourses
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely today, Saturday 18th November 2023. The River is reacting quickly, and rising sharply in response to the rainfall. Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas around Halesworth, Wissett, Chediston, Walpole, Huntingfield, Bramfield and Wrentham. The forecast is for further rain this afternoon and evening, Saturday 18th November. Tomorrow is due to be a dryer day with light rain forecast. Flood water is dangerous. Don't put yourself or others at risk. We are closely monitoring the situation. We will update this message on Sunday 19th November, or as the situation changes.

items.message:

This Flood Alert remains in force due to the high levels in the River Yeo at Sherborne Lake. The River Yeo, River Cam and River Wriggle are likely to rise during Saturday due to the forecast rainfall and may result in further flooding of low-lying land and roads. 
Areas most at risk include the Sparkford to Weston Bampfylde road and Deep Ford Lane, Chetnole.
Please consider weather conditions, local water levels and your flood plan if you have one. Avoid using low lying footpaths, roads and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

Please avoid contact with flood water and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 10:00 on 19/11/23, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are rising on the Ginge Brook as a result of overnight rainfall. Therefore, the risk of flooding remains, especially in the Steventon area.  Further rain is forecast this morning, 18/11/23, with further unsettled weather expected over the coming week with low confidence over exact locations and timings of rain. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. River levels remain high due to rises at the Slad Steanbridge Lane river gauge as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today Saturday 18/11/20223. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid contact with flood water. This message will be updated by 10 am on Sunday 19/11/23 or as the situation changes.

This flood alert has been removed as river levels have fallen back below levels of concern. Further rainfall is forecast at the weekend and we expect levels to rise again into Sunday, 19/11/23. We are closely monitoring the forecast and will re-issue this alert  if necessary.

Further rainfall is forecast however, we continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking the condition of defences.

Further rain is forecast this morning, 18/11/23, with further unsettled weather expected over the coming week with low confidence over exact locations and timings of rain. items.description: River Pang from East Ilsley to Pangbourne and Sulham Brook
items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are steady on the River Pang and Sulham Brook as a result of overnight rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially in the Sulham area. Further rain is forecast this morning, 18/11/23, with further unsettled weather expected over the coming week with low confidence over exact locations and timings of rain. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow, 19/11/23, or as the situation changes.

This message has been issued because there may be some issues with surface water flooding and difficult driving conditions today, Saturday 18th November 2023. The River is reacting quickly, and rising sharply in response to the rainfall. Areas most at risk are the Thoroughfare, Chediston Street, Saxons Way and School Lane in Halesworth, and the A144 and the railway line at Halesworth. The forecast is for further rain this afternoon and evening, Saturday 18th November. Tomorrow is due to be a dryer day with light rain forecast. Flood water is dangerous. Don't put yourself or others at risk. We are closely monitoring the situation. We will update this message on Sunday 19th November, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The River Waveney from Diss and the River Dove to Ellingham, including Bungay
items.message: River levels are now steadily falling. The forecast is for dry weather today, Friday 17 November. Further rain is expected over the weekend some of which could be heavy at times. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

River levels in Hellingly and Alfriston are slowly starting to rise following Saturday morning's rain (18/11/2023). Only minimal flood impacts affecting fields and rural roads are currently expected in both Hellingly and Alfriston. Showers are forecast for Sunday (19/11/2023), with more rain (5-10mm) forecast for Monday (20/11/2023). The Cuckmere and Bull Rivers will rise again. Property flooding could be possible in both Hellingly and Alfriston. In Alfriston, the river could remain higher than normal all week. Please plan to avoid driving through routes susceptible to flooding, including Mill Lane and Church Road, Hellingly and North Street, Alfriston. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 11:00 on 19/11/2023.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Tewks. Upper Pound river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding is reducing.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the River Severn from Tewkesbury to Gloucester. Locations that may be affected include Apperley and Maisemore. Severn Ham, Tewkesbury starts to fill. Levels have now peaked. River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated  by 10:00 on 19/11/23, or as the situation changes.

Further rain is forecast this morning, 18/11/23, with further unsettled weather expected over the coming week with low confidence over exact locations and timings of rain. items.description: River Ouse at York - St George's Field and Queen's Staith
items.message: River levels remain high on the River Ouse in York due to rainfall as a result of Storm Debi. Flooding is expected to affect low lying land, particularly around properties along Queens Staith on South Esplanade, Friars Terrace and Tower Place, St Georges Field car parks and Rowntree Park. The level in York at the Viking recorder is around 3.1m. Further rainfall is forecast for the next few days and we expect levels to rise again this evening into Sunday, 19/11/2023. We will continue to monitor the forecast. The Foss Barrier is being operated. Please monitor local water levels and put your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 3pm on 18/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ouse at York - riverside properties
items.message: River levels remain high on the River Ouse in York in response to recent rainfall in the upper catchment, associated with Storm Debi. Flooding is forecast to affect riverside properties, properties on King's Staith in York and riverside areas through York from Lendal Bridge to Millennium Bridge. Levels in York at the Viking recorder are around 3.1m. The Foss Barrier is in operation. Further rainfall is forecast for the next few days and we expect levels to rise again this evening into Sunday, 19/11/2023. We will continue to monitor the forecast. Please monitor local water levels and weather conditions and put your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 3pm on 18/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message:
This information is correct as of 09:00 on Saturday 18 November 2023. 
The causeway at Welney has 4 centimetres of water on the road. Due to uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. The Environment Agency is liaising with Cambridge and Norfolk Highways who will decide whether to close the road.
The rainfall last night will clear away by lunchtime. There are no issues on Sutton Gault causeway and Earith causeway. We will continue to monitor the situation.
We will update this message by 17:00 on Saturday 18 November 2023.

This flood warning has been removed as river levels have fallen back below levels of concern. There is further rain forecast at the weekend, over the next few days, and we will reissue this warning if necessary.

The Western Rother remains high in Fittleworth. Minor flood impacts affecting fields, gardens and rural roads will continue in Fittleworth. The Western Rother will rise a small amount in all communities following this Saturday's rain (18/11/2023), but minor flood impacts are only expected in Fittleworth. Showers are forecast for Sunday (19/11/2023), with more rain (5-10mm) forecast for Monday (20/11/2023). The Western Rother will rise again. It is currently thought flood impacts will remain minor, affecting fields, gardens and rural roads. However, from Saturday evening (18/11/2023) flood water could potentially approach properties at Lodsbridge and Fittleworth. River levels in Fittleworth could be higher than normal all week. Early actions to reduce potential impacts at Lodsbridge and Fittleworth are encouraged. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 11:00 on 19/11/2023.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Asker, River Brit, River Bride, River Char, River Lim

items.message:
The Flood Alert has now been removed.Â 
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.

The Aldingbourne Rife remains high. Flooding is thought to still be affecting the Tesco car park on Shripney Road, some areas of Durban Road, fields near Shripney Lane and the A259, as well as caravans at Riverside Caravan Centre and Rowan Park Caravan Park. The Aldingbourne Rife will start to slowly rise following Saturday's rain (18/11/2023). The Barnham Rife is already starting to rise. Flood impacts will continue in Bersted. Isolated property flooding could also be possible in Barnham on Saturday afternoon (18/11/2023). Showers are forecast for Sunday (19/11/2023), with more rain (5-10mm) forecast for Monday (20/11/2023). The Aldingbourne Rife might not return to normal until December. Some roads will be affected by flood water. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including Shripney Lane. We are running our pumps at Felpham and keeping grilles clear to help reduce the risk of flooding. We will update this message by 11:00 on 19/11/2023.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station (HEPS) is 8.45 m and is falling. The drain level at HEPS is 7.84 m and very slowly rising.
Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this level exceeds 7.3 m, the road from Muchelney to Long Load above 7.86 m, and the road from Muchelney to Thorney above 7.93 m.
After a mostly dry Friday, a band of rain will return early Saturday morning through to late afternoon. Unsettled weather will continue through the weekend and into Monday 20 November. 
When river levels allow, pumping continues at Huish Episcopi and we are utilising the Parrett Relief Channel to evacuate water.
We will continue to monitor the rainfall and river levels and our staff are checking flood defences and clearing weed screens. This message will be updated by 1pm on Saturday 18/11/2023.
Please consider local water levels and weather conditions and do not walk or drive through flood water.
For water levels on the River Yeo and the drain at HEPS please refer to our website: (check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels).

The Combe Haven in Bulverhythe remains high, and will continue to rise by 30cm over each high tide period. Flooding will continue to affect Bexhill Road Recreation Ground, and possibly some gardens on Bexhill Road in Bulverhythe. The Powdermill Stream in Crowhurst is high but is not expected to reach the levels seen on Tuesday this week. Only minimal flood impacts are expected in Crowhurst. The Powdermill Stream and Combe Haven are rising again following Saturday's rain (18/11/2023), and property flooding could be possible from Saturday afternoon. Showers are forecast for Sunday (19/11/2023), with more rain (5-10mm) forecast for Monday (20/11/2023). The river will be sensitive to any additional rainfall over the rest of winter. Flood protection products are recommended to be kept installed in Crowhurst, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 11:00 on 19/11/2023.

The Aldingbourne Rife remains high. Flooding is thought to still be affecting the Tesco car park on Shripney Road, some areas of Durban Road, fields near Shripney Lane and the A259, as well as caravans at Riverside Caravan Centre and Rowan Park Caravan Park. River levels will start to slowly rise following Saturday's rain (18/11/2023). Showers are forecast on Sunday (19/11/2023), with more rain (5-10mm) forecast for Monday (20/11/2023). The Aldingbourne Rife could rise by about 15cm on Saturday (18/11/2023). With the rest of November forecast to remain unsettled, the Aldingbourne Rife might not return to normal until December. Some roads will be affected by flood water. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including Shripney Lane. We are running our pumps at Felpham and keeping grilles clear to help reduce the risk of flooding. We will update this message by 11:00 on 19/11/2023.

items.description: Rivers Yeo and Parrett, downstream of Yeovil to Steart

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Parrett, River Yeo, Cary, Sowy, Kings Sedgemoor Drain

items.message:
After a mostly dry Friday, a band of rain will return early Saturday morning through to late afternoon. Unsettled weather will continue through the weekend and into Monday 20 November. 
This Flood Alert remains in force due to the flooding of large areas of the Somerset Levels and Moors. Flood water may affect the Ilchester to Yeovilton road at the end of the runway, the Mudford to Limington road, the road and properties at the south end of Westover Trading Estate.
We are utilising our pumping stations, including additional temporary pumps, when river levels allow. The Parrett Relief Channel is being used to evacuate the water away from the Parrett-Tone confluence.
Please consider weather conditions, local water levels and your flood plan if you have one. Avoid using low lying footpaths, roads and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
We will continue to monitor the rainfall and river levels and our staff are checking flood defences and clearing weed screens. This message will be updated by 1pm on Saturday 18/11/2023.

River levels are rising again on the River Derwent at Buttercrambe. Flooding is expected in this area and levels are expected to remain high this weekend. Flooding remains a risk near the River Derwent, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around Buttercrambe Mill at Buttercrambe Bridge. Further rain is expected over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please take action to protect yourself and your property and monitor local weather and river conditions. Avoid contact with, walking or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 5pm on 18/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Hull, Holderness Drain, Barmston Drain

items.message: River levels remain high on the Beverley and Barmston Drain, Frodingham Beck, River Hull and Roam Drain due to Storm Debi. Areas most at risk include the Upper Hull area including Kilham, Nafferton, Driffield, Bainton, North Dalton, Leconfield, Leven, Brandesburton, North Frodingham and Beeford. Further rain is forecast for the next few days and we expect levels to stay high. We will continue to monitor the forecast. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 8pm on 18/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected.

River levels are forecast to rise on the Lower River Loddon as a result of recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of roads and farmland is expected this afternoon 18/11/23, especially in the Sindlesham area. This morning's rain will gradually clear to leave a dry day. We expect river levels to begin rising at approximately 14:30 on 18/11/23.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are in the area clearing trash screens. 
 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated this evening 18/11/23 or if the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Plym, Tory Brook, Long Brook

items.message:
Organised bands of rainfall will move across the county from mid-afternoon on Friday 17th November, until late morning Saturday. There may be some intense localised downpours during the early hours. Overall accumulations across the period could be up to 20mm widely, and up to 40mm on higher ground. This could lead to further rises in river levels, peaking during the early hours and into Saturday morning, which may result in flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river.   

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated on Saturday morning or earlier if the situation changes.

We expect minor and localised flooding to affect low lying land and roads close to the rivers. Please avoid using low lying land or footpaths near local watercourses. Further rainfall is forecast during the course of this morning until around 14:00 on Saturday 18 November 2023. Our incident response staff are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. Please stay aware in case further warnings are issued.  
This message will be updated this evening, 18 November 2023, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.

River levels are slowly falling on the River Loddon in the Twyford area. This morning's 18/11/23 rain will gradually clear to leave a dry day. We expect river levels to rise this afternoon in response to the recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of roads and low lying land remains possible.

We are closely monitoring the situation. 

Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated this evening 18/11/23, or if the situation changes.

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.

River levels are high but are slowly falling on the River Thames following recent rainfall. Flooding of roads and low lying land remains possible. This morning's 18/11/23 rain will gradually clear to leave a dry day. We expect river levels to continue to slowly fall. 

We are closely monitoring the situation. 

Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated this evening 18/11/23, or if the situation changes.

The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.51 m and steady. Water will enter Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45 m.
The drain level at Currymoor is 5.79 m and is slowly rising. 
After a mostly dry Friday, a band of rain will return early Saturday morning through to late afternoon. Unsettled weather will continue through the weekend and into Monday 20 November. 
We will continue to monitor the rainfall and river levels and our staff are checking flood defences and clearing weed screens.
We are pumping at Currymoor and Saltmoor pumping stations when river levels allow and have deployed additional temporary pumps at both stations and at Elsonâs Clyce. The Parrett Relief Channel is being used to evacuate the water away.
Please consider weather conditions, local water levels and your flood plan if you have one. Avoid using low lying footpaths, roads and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated before 1pm on Saturday 18 November.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the West of Dorset
items.message: A gradual easing of conditions over the past week is likely to be reversed following a fresh band of heavy rain in the next 24 hours. We do not expect property flooding at this stage, but some roads, including from Winterborne Abbas to Winterborne Came are likely to be flooded once more. Avoid driving through flood water if at all possible as your bow wave can cause damage to nearby homes. EA staff will continue to monitor the situation locally and will update this message should the situation change.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Upper Og Valley
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to recent rainfall and have remained high at our observation borehole in Draycot Foliat in the Og Valley area. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and remain at a level where communities may be affected by flooding from groundwater over the coming days. Groundwater levels in the area are currently stable but remain responsive to rainfall. Further rainfall is forecast this morning, 18/11/23, with further unsettled weather expected over the coming week with low confidence over exact locations and timings of rain.

Groundwater level will continue to remain high and may still impact low lying gardens and cellars. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.
We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message by 25/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising on the River Piddle.
Areas most at risk include tributaries between Alton Pancras and Wareham.
Flooding is possible at tributaries between Alton Pancras and Wareham from 09:00 AM on 18/11/2023.
Further light rainfall is forecast this afternoon.
River levels are high but steady, but the risk of flooding to low-lying land remains.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Cranborne Chase area
items.message: A gradual easing of conditions over the past week is likely to be reversed following a fresh band of heavy rain in the next 24 hours. We do not expect property flooding at this stage, but some roads, including Stubhampton to Tarrant Hinton, Farnham to Gussage St Andrew and Wyke Down to Monkton up Wimborne are likely to be impassable once more. Avoid driving through flood water if at all possible as your bow wave can cause damage to nearby homes. EA staff will continue to monitor the situation locally and will update this message should the situation change.

The River Lavant is high and rising following heavy rain overnight. Minor flood impacts could affect fields, rural roads and gardens between West Dean and Westhampnett. In East Lavant water may affect Sheepwash Lane, Pook Lane and the Green, and possibly access bridges over the river. Flood water could affect gardens and approach properties at The Sadlers, Westhampnett. Showers are forecast for Sunday (19/11/2023) and more rain (5-10mm) on Monday (20/11/2023). The river should slowly fall by Sunday morning, but will be higher than normal over the next few days. Land could remain flooded for the next few days. Water levels will remain higher than normal and the river will be sensitive to any additional rainfall. Some roads could be affected by flood water. Plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding including Sheepwash Lane. If you see a blockage affecting the flow in the river, please call our incident hotline on 0800 80 70 60. We are managing structures in Westhampnett to reduce the flood risk on the River Lavant. We will update this message by 11:00 on 19/11/2023.

items.description: River Leach from Northleach to Mill Lane near Lechlade
items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high, but falling, on the River Leach as a result of previous heavy rainfall. Therefore, the risk of flooding remains, especially in the Lechlade area.  Further rain is forecast this morning, 18/11/23, with further unsettled weather expected over the coming week with low confidence over exact locations and timings of rain. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow, 19/11/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames from Hurley to Cookham
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.

River levels are high but are slowly falling on the River Thames from Hurley to Cookham following recent rainfall. Flooding of roads and low lying land remains possible. This morning's 18/11/23 rain will gradually clear to leave a dry day. We expect river levels to continue to slowly fall. 

We are closely monitoring the situation. 

Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated this evening 18/11/23, or if the situation changes.

This flood warning has been removed as river levels have fallen back below levels of concern. Further rainfall is forecast at the weekend and we expect levels to rise again into Sunday, 19/11/23. We are closely monitoring the forecast and will re-issue this warning if necessary.

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, North Somerset, Somerset
floodArea.riverOrSea: River Chew, Chew Stoke Stream, Winford Brook

items.message:
The flood forecast has changed significantly. As a result, there is no longer a risk of flooding in the area.
Further rain is expected today, the 18th of November and the 19th November 2023 but limited response expected from the rivers.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.
